info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 7.

(2, 1).clue: Costume designers win awards named for Irene Sharaff, who designed Jet & Shark costumes for this 1957 musical

(4, 1).clue: Founded in 1917 by Father Flanagan for homeless & abused waifs, it was made a municipality in 1936

(5, 1).clue: You'll need your platinum card when shopping along the avenue posted here in this city

(6, 1).clue: A language of the Middle East, it was added as the sixth language of the U.N. General Assembly in 1973

(2, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew gondolas across the stage of the Majestic Theatre in New York.)  On June 5, 1988, "Phantom Of The Opera" won seven of these awards, & you can see why it won for scenic design and lighting

(3, 2).clue: It's the office or position of a judge, or where he sits

(4, 2).clue: The alleged site of Doubleday's invention of baseball, this N.Y. village is home to Baseball's Hall of Fame

(5, 2).clue: Hopefully you won't rue the day you see the "Rue" sign seen here in this Louisiana district

(6, 2).clue: This sixth planet from the Sun was first visited by Pioneer 11 in 1979

(2, 3).clue: Paul Huntley is B'way's master of these; you might flip yours over the ones he designed for "Hairspray"

(4, 3).clue: An armistice to end the Korean War was signed at this village in July 1953

(5, 3).clue: When we're near the sign seen here, it's time to go tubing in this city

(6, 3).clue: Number corresponding to 10 to the sixth power

(2, 4).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from the New Amsterdam Theatre.)  The New Amsterdam Theatre is a fine example of this art style that features vines, flowers & flowing hair

(3, 4).clue: It can mean to make white, or to boil fruit or vegetables briefly, then plunge them into cold water

(4, 4).clue: This blue cheese is named for a village that's now a suburb of Milan, not a snake-haired monster

(5, 4).clue: If you've stopped for a breather next to this sign, it's only 100 more miles northeast to this capital

(6, 4).clue: From the Latin for "sixth hour", it's an early afternoon rest or nap

(2, 5).clue: Peter Foy revolutionized stage flying with the "inter-related pendulum" he designed for this 1954 musical

(3, 5).clue: In mythology Triton could calm or stir the waters by blowing this shell

(4, 5).clue: In the Bible, only John's gospel mentions this village in Galilee as the site of Jesus' wedding feast miracle

(5, 5).clue: The sign seen here might cross your mind if you're driving in this country

(6, 5).clue: Per the text of the Sixth Amendment, the accused must know the charge & "be confronted with" these

(1, 1).clue: Cleopatra (soprano) & Curio (bass) appear in Handel's opera about this man (contralto) in Egypt

(2, 1).clue: Founded in 1922, the international brotherhood of these people opposes revealing their trade secrets

(3, 1).clue: Bergamot & Seville are types of this fruit

(4, 1).clue: Taking kickbacks from Baltimore contractors helped oust him from office in the 1970s

(5, 1).clue: He's won 7 MVP awards, far more than anyone else in his sport

(6, 1).clue: Tums & Rolaids are competitors of this antacid introduced in 1949

(1, 2).clue: He wrote the ragtime opera "A Guest of Honor"

(2, 2).clue: (Honorary Clue Crew member Dayna Devon from Extra reports from an awards show.)  The Golden Globe Awards are given by the HFPA, a group whose reporters hail from places like Argentina, Egypt & Taiwan

(3, 2).clue: In the U.S. the yellow Cavendish is the most popular type of this fruit

(4, 2).clue: After failing to create his own country in the West, he asked Napoleon to help him conquer Florida

(5, 2).clue: Use running or Flemish bonds while laying these to make sure your house won't get blown down

(6, 2).clue: Last name of acting siblings Maggie & Jake

(1, 3).clue: This Verdi opera was first performed on Dec. 24, 1871, in Cairo

(2, 3).clue: Harold Arlen & Doc Pomus are members of these people's Hall of Fame & Johnny Mercer was a co-founder

(3, 3).clue: When the name of this fruit is preceded by "sugar", it refers to a kind of candy

(4, 3).clue: Schuyler Colfax, this ex-general's vice president, pleaded that bribe money given to him was for the sale of a piano

(5, 3).clue: This 1915 Maugham work details the life & loves of Philip Carey

(6, 3).clue: From the Arabic, it's a low bow, or a salutation meaning "peace"

(1, 4).clue: In a Puccini opera, he marries then abandons Cio-Cio-San

(2, 4).clue: Head of the Motion Picture Association of America, 1966-2004, he created the current movie rating system

(3, 4).clue: Now is the time to name this tart berry, seen here

(4, 4).clue: This V.P. diverted attention from his slush fund by explaining his wife had a cloth coat & not a mink

(5, 4).clue: In 1968, he became the first African-American man to be placed in nomination for the VP candidacy of a major party

(6, 4).clue: This former province of South Africa was bounded by Cape Province on the west

(1, 5).clue: In a Wagner opera, this title knight tells Elsa he'll marry her so long as she never asks his identity

(2, 5).clue: Spanish for "we", this organization was founded by Ricardo Montalban to improve the image of Latinos on screen

(3, 5).clue: A wekiwa sometimes called a lavender gem is a cross between a tangelo & a white one of these

(4, 5).clue: Levi Morton was soiled by the Peruvian guano scandal before taking office in 1889 for this president

(5, 5).clue: These covalent bonds are largely responsible for the attraction between water molecules

(0, 0).clue: These 2 writers of lavish prose, born in North Carolina & Virginia 30 years apart, have the same first & last name
